posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Android

I've got a note 10.1 2014 LTE edition after I dropped my nexus and I love it.

>take notes at meetings
>watch movies on pane trips
>stream music and movies to TV and Bluetooth speakers at home and at friends place
>quickly sketch out UI ideas I have in my mind
>browsing the web is 100x better than on a mobile device
>share random things or look up questions when I'm with friends and we can't find the answer to something

It's not 100% geared for work, it's more of a really convenient thing to always have on me.

>>45842240
http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/lifecycle
>What is the difference between mainstream support and extended support?

>Mainstream support—Microsoft will offer mainstream support for a minimum of 5 years from the date of a product's general availability, or for 2 years after the successor product is released, whichever is longer. For example, if you buy a new version of Windows and five years later another version is released, you will still have two years of support left for the previous version.

>Extended support—Microsoft will offer extended support for either a minimum of 5 years from the date of a product's general availability, or for 2 years after the second successor product (two versions later) is released, whichever is longer.

>For more details on the difference between mainstream support and extended support, refer to the Microsoft Support

posts.com:
This is the Lisp General, ask any and all Lisp questions here. Below is a link to the general's pastebin which contains many links to various books, documentation, websites, and other interesting information.
Check the pastebin first:

http://pastebin.com/u/g-lisp-general

>Here's the /g/ wiki's page on Lisp:
http://wiki.installgentoo.com/index.php?title=Lisp

>To foster discussion:
Which dialect do you prefer?
Do you use Emacs or a different lisp-based editor?
What was your first experience with lisp?
What have you made in lisp?
What is your favorite Lisp program?
What do you like about Lisp?
How do you think Lisp is (one of) the superior programming language(s)?
How long have you been programming in Lisp?
What are your favorite Lisp resources? Please share, preferably links!
Is Lisp your main programming language or not? Regardless, what do you primarily use it for?
What would you like to see in the Lisp general?
What was your favorite aspect of the Lisp machines?
Do you think we'll ever get something similar to the LispMs again?
What is your preferred method of documenting your code?
In the dialects that allow it, do you make many reader macros or not?
Do you use more than one dialect? What are they and which do you prefer?
What do you consider the criteria for what constitutes a Lisp to be?
What is your favorite function in your chosen dialect(s)?
The previous thread:

https://rbt.asia/g/thread/45778748

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>45839530
>> symbolic computation
When people say this, do they mean specifically using symbols to represent information as opposed to numbers (or enums, which are more or less just globals bound to numbers)?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>45841498
>AspectL
>pointcut functionality doesn't make much sense in Common Lisp
Anyone know why?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>45842272
To me, it means that the "identifiers" used in the language are objects themselves. For example, in C you may declare "int i;", but "i" is just the way you refer to a memory location in C. In Lisp however, such names are objects themselves (symbols), with attributes, and "variables" are actually just bindings to these names.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hey /g/

Is it so hard to have a smartphone that shoots well during low light situations?

Every phone and their grandmother can shoot amazing and vibrant shots during the day with ideal lighting. However, their cameras become useless after sunset. (flash is abysmal in smartphones, with direct LED lighting washing out the entire picture).

After spending a bit looking into this, the best 'low light' as well as regular phone camera that I was able to filter out was a Nokia 1020. That came out MONTHS ago!! Since no one bouth one because, lol Windows phone, even Nokia is moving away from camera focus to a pure 'specs' battle (screen size, etc).

tl;dr - any /g/ents have suggestions for smartphones that work well in low light/darkness? Anything better out there than a Nokia 1020??

PS: please do not bring up point and shoot cameras - we're limiting ourselves to smartphones here.
